'''Erik Akkersdijk''' (born 7 October 1989 in [[Enschede]], [[Netherlands|The Netherlands]]) is a Dutch [[Rubik's Cube]] [[Speedcubing|speedsolver]].

In 2008, he set several Rubik's Cube world records.

He started cubing in August 2005. He is globally known as one of the best speedcubers in the world.
Akkersdijk graduated as Bachelor of Applied Science on Environmental Science at [[Saxion University of Applied Sciences]] in [[Deventer]].<ref>http://nl.linkedin.com/pub/erik-akkersdijk/56/a1a/a</ref>

==Media appearances==
[[File:Erik Akkersdijk is solving a 3×3×3 Rubik's Cube in 10.50s.ogv|thumb|thumbtime=20|Erik Akkersdijk is solving a Rubik's Cube in 10.50s]]
After he set the world record of 7.08 seconds Akkersdijk appeared on a show in The Netherlands called 'Ik wed dat ik het kan' (I bet I can do it) where he solved a cube with his feet in 1 minute 30 seconds and won €1000. In 2016 Akkersdijk reappeared in the show, this time solving three Rubik's cubes blindfolded in 3 minutes, winning another €1000.
He also appeared on the German Stern TV hosted by the well-known [[Günther Jauch]].
On his YouTube channel, frk17, videos are uploaded by Akkersdijk explaining or showing his speedcubing skills. There is also a YouTube video of him solving the 3x3x3 in 7.08, filmed by his friend.

pages.title: Ron van Bruchem
pages.text:
[[File:Ron van Bruchem at Estonian Open 2018.jpg|thumb|Ron van Bruchem at Estonian Open 2018]]
'''Ron van Bruchem''' (born 20 April 1967) is a well known [[Netherlands|Dutch]] [[speedcubing|speedcuber]] living in [[Amstelveen]]. He helped create the current resurge of [[Rubik's Cube]] enthusiasm by co-founding the international speedcubing community and organizing international competitions. He is also a founder, delegate and former chairman of the [[World Cube Association]], an organization aiming at the spread of speedcubing as a regulated sport. He is also the host of the website speedcubing.com.

In 1999 the first modern age speedcubers found each other on internet via Rubik's Games, a computer game with an electronic version of Rubik's Cube. [[Chris Hardwick (speed cuber)|Chris Hardwick]] from Raleigh, NC founded a Yahoo Group Speedsolvingrubikscube and the Unofficial World Records, a place where cubers could post their personal records. Ron van Bruchem started speedcubing.com together with his friend Ton Dennenbroek, an avid puzzle collector. Because the first cubers were living all over the world they wanted to organize a competition where they could all meet. After failing in 2001, under guidance of Dan Gosbee they finally succeeded to organize World Championship 2003 in Toronto. This first modern age Rubik's Cube competition was a huge success, but there were lots of issues because of the lack of good regulations. After WC 2003 Ron van Bruchem and [[Tyson Mao]] started organizing competitions in The Netherlands/Germany and at Caltech University in USA. In 2004 they started the [[World Cube Association]] which nowadays organizes competitions in over 90 countries.

==World records==
Ron van Bruchem has held official world records for solving the Rubik's Cube (9.55 seconds) set at the Dutch Nationals 2007 (lost 2008), the 5x5x5 cube in 2006 (1:47.22 min) set at Belgian Open 2006 (lost 2006), and 2x2x2 cube (2.65 seconds) set at UK Open 2007 (lost 2008).
He is currently the fastest Rubik's Cube solver over 30 years old, which title he won at the World Championship Rubik's Cube 2013 in [[Las Vegas]], NV, USA.

==Personal life==
Ron van Bruchem was born in [[Hilversum]], The Netherlands. He was partially raised in a facility for children of [[Salvation Army]]. After his studies he has been working for [[Rabobank]] for over 25 years now.
Ron has a daughter Julia (December 1997).

==External links==
*[http://www.worldcubeassociation.org/results/p.php?i=2003BRUC01 Ron van Bruchem's listing] on http://www.worldcubeassociation.org

'''Mats Valk''' (born 4 May 1996) is a [[Netherlands|Dutch]] [[Rubik's Cube]] [[Speedcubing|speedsolver]]. He broke the Rubik's cube single solve world record twice with times of 5.55 seconds in 2013 and 4.74 seconds in 2016. He won the Rubik's Cube European Championship in 2018<ref>{{cite web |title=Mats Valk wins WCA European Championship 2018, in Madrid, Spain |url=https://www.worldcubeassociation.org/posts/mats-valk-wins-wca-european-championship-2018-in-madrid-spain |website=World Cube Association |accessdate=23 July 2018 |date=23 July 2018}}</ref> and was runner-up for 3x3x3 at the Rubik's Cube World Championships in 2013 and 2015 and won the European Championship 2018.

==Biography==

Valk was born and raised in [[Amstelveen]], [[Netherlands|the Netherlands]], a suburb of the Dutch capital [[Amsterdam]].

Valk is most famous for breaking the [[Rubik's Cube|Rubik's cube]] world record twice and being the runner-up at both the Rubik's cube world championships of 2013<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rIrpqdqqs6c |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2017-01-18 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170201235337/https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rIrpqdqqs6c |archivedate=2017-02-01 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.worldcubeassociation.org/competitions/WC2013/results/podiums |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2017-01-15 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170118070601/https://www.worldcubeassociation.org/competitions/WC2013/results/podiums |archivedate=2017-01-18 |df= }}</ref> and 2015.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=gW8oZzPkVok&t=126s |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2017-01-18 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170202000353/https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=gW8oZzPkVok&t=126s |archivedate=2017-02-02 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.worldcubeassociation.org/competitions/WC2015/results/podiums |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2017-01-15 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170118070850/https://www.worldcubeassociation.org/competitions/WC2015/results/podiums |archivedate=2017-01-18 |df= }}</ref> He first broke the world record with a time of 5.55 seconds at the Zonhoven Open 2013 in Belgium on 3 March 2013. This record stood for over 2 years. He later broke the world record again with a time of 4.74 seconds at the Jawa Timur Open 2016 in Indonesia on 6 November 2016. In December 2016, Valk looked on as [[Feliks Zemdegs]] overtook his world record by just 0.01 seconds.

Valk has also set three 4x4x4 world records, two for single solve and one for an average of 5.  His second single world record, 26.77 seconds on 15 April 2012, was the first official 4x4x4 solve under 30 seconds. Altogether, Valk has broken 5 [[World Cube Association|WCA]] world records, 17 European records, and 127 Dutch national records. Valk also currently holds the world record for solving the most Rubik's cubes in 1 hour, 374 cubes, set in Paris on 21 October 2015.

Valk is also known as a creator of the VLS (Valk Last Slot) 3x3x3 algorithm set, which correctly orients the last layer while inserting the last corner-edge pair of the first two layers. Valk used one of these algorithms to complete the cube in his 2016 3x3x3 world record.

== The Valk ==
Valk is also a businessman: he collaborated with the Chinese brand QiYi MoFangGe to set up his own brand, The Valk, creating cubes according to his own specifications. The design of the mechanism and the performance of the cube has to be approved by Valk himself before the cube is mass-produced and sold. This is to secure all cubes released under this brand are top quality. The first cube released under this brand was the Valk3<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=P9ZhG1p1y-4&t=3s |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2017-01-18 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170202020114/https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=P9ZhG1p1y-4&t=3s |archivedate=2017-02-02 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://thecubicle.us/valk-p-7148.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2017-01-15 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161103041825/https://thecubicle.us/valk-p-7148.html |archivedate=2016-11-03 |df= }}</ref> on 15 August 2016. This cube has been used by many other world class speedcubers, including Patrick Ponce's former world record single. The size of the cube (5.55 cm each side) is a reference to his first Rubik's cube world record. He set his 2016 3x3x3 world record using a special magnetized version of this cube put together by TheCubicle.us, known as the Cubicle Valk3 M. In addition, QiYi released another Valk 3x3, the Valk Power and Power M, short for Valk Power Magnetic.

pages.title: Édouard Chambon
Gilles Roux
pages.text:
'''Gilles Roux''' (born January 20, 1971) is a [[France|French]] [[Speedcubing|speedcuber]] primarily known for inventing a [[Rubik's Cube|3x3x3]] method, the Roux Method, and achieving fast times with it.

== WCA ==
Gilles was a member of the [[World Cube Association]] Board from October 2004 until November 1, 2008. During his time as a board member, Gilles helped organize many competitions as a WCA delegate. He also contributed to WCA by creating much needed regulations which would in turn help out cubers all over the world. Presently, Gilles is a [[technical advisor]] for the WCA and assists when needed.<ref>http://www.worldcubeassociation.org/forum/viewtopic.php?f=9&t=468</ref>

== Roux method ==
Over a span of years, Gilles developed his own method to solving the 3x3x3 cube. Using a smaller quantity of memorized [[algorithm]]s than most methods of solving, Roux still found his method to be fast and efficient. The first step of the Roux method is to form a 3×2×1 block. The 3×2×1 block is usually placed in the lower portion of the left layer. The second step is to create another 3×2×1 on the opposite side. The remaining four corners are then solved using a set of algorithms known as CMLL (Corners of the Last Layer, without regards to the M-slice), which leaves six edges and four centers that are solved in the last step.

== Official results ==
For official results, solves must be completed in a [[competition]] held by the WCA. In competition, Gilles has recorded a single solve of 10.06 seconds, ranking him just out the top one thousand solvers in the world (as of 01/01/15). His best average of 5 was set on 16 September 2011 at 13.03.<ref>http://www.worldcubeassociation.org/results/p.php?i=2004ROUX01</ref> Also his greatest achieved fewest moves competition for the standard 3x3x3 is 31, being part of the "31 club", coming to a draw with another known cuber and creator of popular method of solving, [[Lars Petrus]].

==See also==

* [[Speedcubing]]
* [[Jessica Fridrich]]
* [[Lars Petrus]]
* [[World Cube Association]]

pages.title: Sebastian Weyer
pages.text:
'''Sebastian Weyer''' is a [[Germany|German]] [[Rubik's cube]] [[speedcuber|speedsolver]] who specializes in [[Rubik's Revenge|4x4x4]] solving. Weyer has broken the 4x4x4 single solve world record 7 times and the average of five solves record 9 times. He set his first world record on 1 May 2011.<ref>[[World Cube Association]] - [https://www.worldcubeassociation.org/persons/2010WEYE02?tab=records Sebastian Weyer Records]</ref>

Weyer last held the world record for single [[Rubik's Revenge|4x4x4]] solve on 27 May 2018, and last held the world record for average of five solves on 12 May 2018.<ref>[[World Cube Association]] - [https://www.worldcubeassociation.org/results/regions.php?eventId=444&history=History 4x4x4 History]</ref>

Weyer holds the European records for single and average of five [[Rubik's Revenge|4x4x4]] solves, 18.84 seconds and 21.46 seconds, respectively, and for average of five [[Professor's Cube|5x5x5]] solves, 47.34 seconds.<ref>[[World Cube Association]] - [https://www.worldcubeassociation.org/results/regions.php?regionId=_Europe European Records]</ref>

Weyer has attended two World Championships: 2013 and 2017.  At the 2013 World Championship in [[Las Vegas]], Weyer placed 2nd in 4x4x4 and 3rd in [[Rubik's Cube|3x3x3]].<ref>[[World Cube Association]] - [https://www.worldcubeassociation.org/competitions/WC2013/results/podiums World Championship 2013 podiums]</ref>  At the 2017 World Championship in [[Paris]], Weyer won the 4x4x4 event.<ref>[[World Cube Association]] - [https://www.worldcubeassociation.org/competitions/WC2017/results/podiums World Championship 2017 podiums]</ref>

Weyer is the brother of speedcuber Philipp Weyer,<ref>Speedsolving.com - [https://www.speedsolving.com/wiki/index.php/Sebastian_Weyer Sebastian Weyer]</ref> who holds the European record for average of five [[Rubik's Cube|3x3x3]] solves.<ref>[[World Cube Association]] - [https://www.worldcubeassociation.org/results/regions.php?regionId=_Europe&eventId=333 European 3x3x3 Records]</ref>

pages.title: Mátyás Kuti
pages.text:
{{Orphan|date=September 2013}}

'''Mátyás Kuti''' is a [[Hungarian people|Hungarian]] [[Rubik's Cube]] and [[Rubik's Magic]] solver. During 2007 and 2008 he held world records in many events.<ref name="WCA Page">{{cite web|url=http://worldcubeassociation.org/results/p.php?i=2006KUTI01|title=World Cube Association Official Results}}</ref> However, in February 2008, after determining that he had cheated in blindfolded events by peeking at the cube, the [[World Cube Association]] revoked all of his blindfold records and banned him for three years from WCA competitions.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://worldcubeassociation.org/forum/viewtopic.php?f=9&t=388|title=Important announcement about blindfold solving}}</ref>

'''Krishnam Raju Gadiraju''' (born 24 May 1989)<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.coca-colaindia.com/stories/wr-one-hand-rubik-s-cube-solving-24-hr|title=WR: One-Hand Rubik’s Cube Solving (24 hr)|work=coca-colaindia.com}}</ref> is an Indian [[speedcubing|speedcuber]]<ref name="wcaor">{{cite web| title = 'World Cube Association - Official Results'| url = https://www.worldcubeassociation.org/results/p.php?i=2013GADI01| }}</ref><ref name=TOI>{{cite web|url=https://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/bengaluru/he-can-solve-rubiks-cube-underwater/articleshow/61622059.cms|title=He can solve Rubik’s Cube underwater|newspaper=The Times of India | date=13 November 2017 | first=Deepika | last=Burli | accessdate=18 October 2018 }}</ref> and [[Unicycle|unicyclist]]<ref name="TheNewIndianExpressor">{{cite web|url=http://www.newindianexpress.com/cities/bengaluru/2018/nov/06/bangalore-boy-becomes-first-indian-to-set-record-in-speed-solving-unicycling-1894682.html|title=Bangalore boy becomes first Indian to set record in speed solving, unicycling|newspaper=The New Indian Express | date=6 November 2018 | first=Akhila | last=Damodaran | accessdate=6 November 2018 }}</ref>. He is a six-time world record holder<ref name="TOIor">{{cite web|url=https://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/india/timestopten/msid-66607947,card-66609215.cms|title=Faster than Bolt, on a different field|newspaper=The Times of India | date=19 November 2018 | accessdate=19 November 2018 }}</ref> and the first Indian to ever set a world record in [[speedcubing|speedcubing]] and [[Unicycle|unicycling]]<ref name="TheNewIndianExpressor">{{cite web|url=http://www.newindianexpress.com/cities/bengaluru/2018/nov/06/bangalore-boy-becomes-first-indian-to-set-record-in-speed-solving-unicycling-1894682.html|title=Bangalore boy becomes first Indian to set record in speed solving, unicycling|newspaper=The New Indian Express | date=6 November 2018 | first=Akhila | last=Damodaran | accessdate=6 November 2018 }}</ref>. 

On 19 October 2014, Gadiraju solved 2,176 rubik's cubes with one hand in 24 hours and entered into the [[Guinness World Records]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.instagram.com/p/z_fMCMiaTB/|title=Instagram post by Vamsi K Raju Gadiraju • Mar 9, 2015 at 3:32am UTC|work=instagram.com}}</ref> On 19 October 2016, Gadiraju achieved his second [[Guinness World Record]] title after he solved 170 rubik's cubes on a unicycle, beating the former record of 117 cubes held by Owen Farmer, USA.<ref name="TOIor">{{cite web|url=https://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/india/timestopten/msid-66607947,card-66609215.cms|title=Faster than Bolt, on a different field|newspaper=The Times of India | date=19 November 2018 | accessdate=19 November 2018 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thehindu.com/news/cities/bangalore/Youth-solves-Rubik%E2%80%99s-Cube-165-times-while-riding-a-unicycle/article16077157.ece/|title=Youth solves Rubik’s Cube 165 times while riding a unicycle|work=thehindu.com}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.instagram.com/p/BQA3CFABGVT/|title=Krishnam Raju Gadiraju • 2 February 2017|work=instagram.com}}</ref> Gadiraju is currently the world's fastest [[Soma cube]] solver.<ref name=TOI /> On 19 October 2017, he solved the soma cube officially in 2.93 seconds.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.guinnessworldrecords.com/world-records/435864-fastest-time-to-complete-a-soma-cube/|title=Fastest time to complete a Soma cube|work=guinnessworldrecords.com}}</ref> On the same day, with a time of 53.86 seconds, Gadiraju broke the world record for the fastest time to complete two Rubik's cubes simultaneously underwater.<ref>{{cite news| title = 'Bangalore boy becomes first Indian to set record in speed solving, unicycling'| url = http://www.newindianexpress.com/cities/bengaluru/2018/nov/06/bangalore-boy-becomes-first-indian-to-set-record-in-speed-solving-unicycling-1894682.html| date = 6 Nov 2018 | work=The New Indian Express}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.instagram.com/p/BdlHz74njM5/|title=Krishnam Raju Gadiraju • 6 January 2018|work=instagram.com}}</ref> On 19 October 2018, he solved a [[Gear Cube]] in a world record time of 3.79 seconds and a [[Rubik's Magic]] blindfolded in 2.99 seconds, also a world record.<ref name="TOIor">{{cite web|url=https://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/india/timestopten/msid-66607947,card-66609215.cms|title=Faster than Bolt, on a different field|newspaper=The Times of India | date=19 November 2018 | accessdate=19 November 2018 }}</ref>

He is a competitive chess player representing [[Karnataka]] at [[FIDE|World Chess Federation]] competitions.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ratings.fide.com/card.phtml?event=25683144|title=Krishnam Raju Gadiraju FIDE Chess Profile - Players Arbiters Trainers|work=ratings.fide.com}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://aicf.in/player/25683144/|title=Player - Page 25683144 - All India Chess Federation|work=aicf.in}}</ref> He holds the title Arena Candidate Master. <ref>{{cite web|url=http://ratings.fide.com/card.phtml?event=25683144|title=Krishnam Raju Gadiraju FIDE Chess Profile - Players Arbiters Trainers|work=ratings.fide.com}}</ref> Gadiraju is also a [[Memory sport|memory athlete]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.world-memory-statistics.com/competitor.php?id=3301|title=Competitors: Krishnam Raju GADIRAJU|work=world-memory-statistics.com}}</ref> 

In February 2017, he was featured in the [[Limca Book of Records]].<ref>{{cite news| title = 'Bangalore boy becomes first Indian to set record in speed solving, unicycling'| url = http://www.newindianexpress.com/cities/bengaluru/2018/nov/06/bangalore-boy-becomes-first-indian-to-set-record-in-speed-solving-unicycling-1894682.html| date = 6 Nov 2018 | work=The New Indian Express}}</ref>

==Media appearances==

19 Oct 2014 - The Hindu<ref>{{cite news| title = 'City youth ensures Guinness record'| url = http://www.thehindu.com/news/cities/Hyderabad/City-youth-ensures-Guinness-record/article11076897.ece| date = 19 October 2014 | work=The Hindu}}</ref>

20 Oct 2014 - The New Indian Express<ref>{{cite news| title = 'World's Fastest Rubik's Cube Solver'| url = http://www.newindianexpress.com/cities/hyderabad/2014/oct/20/Worlds-Fastest-Rubiks-Cube-Solver-673710.html| date = 20 October 2014 | work=The New Indian Express}}</ref>

21 Oct 2016 - The Hindu<ref>{{cite news| title = 'Youth solves Rubik’s Cube 165 times while riding a unicycle'| url = http://www.thehindu.com/news/cities/bangalore/Youth-solves-Rubik%E2%80%99s-Cube-165-times-while-riding-a-unicycle/article16077157.ece| date = 21 October 2016 | work=The Hindu}}</ref>

19 Mar 2017 - Bangalore Mirror Indiatimes<ref>{{cite news| title = 'Fastest Finger First'| url = http://bangaloremirror.indiatimes.com/columns/sunday-read/fastest-finger-first/articleshow/57709572.cms| date = 19 March 2017 | work=Bangalore Mirror Indiatimes}}</ref>

13 Nov 2017 - Times of India<ref>{{cite news| title = 'He can solve Rubik’s Cube underwater'| url = https://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/bengaluru/he-can-solve-rubiks-cube-underwater/articleshow/61622059.cms| date = 13 November 2017 | work=Times of India}}</ref>

10 Jan 2018 - Coca-cola <ref>{{cite news| title = 'WR: One-Hand Rubik’s Cube Solving (24 hr)'| url = https://www.coca-colaindia.com/stories/wr-one-hand-rubik-s-cube-solving-24-hr| date = 10 January 2018 | work=Coca-cola}}</ref>

2 Sep 2018 - BBC News<ref>{{cite news| title = 'Solving two Rubik Cubes underwater with two hands at a time BBC News Telugu'| url = https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rb3fmTp2DjQ| date = 2 September 2018 | work=BBC News}}</ref>

6 Nov 2018 - The New Indian Express<ref>{{cite news| title = 'Bangalore boy becomes first Indian to set record in speed solving, unicycling'| url = http://www.newindianexpress.com/cities/bengaluru/2018/nov/06/bangalore-boy-becomes-first-indian-to-set-record-in-speed-solving-unicycling-1894682.html| date = 6 Nov 2018 | work=The New Indian Express}}</ref>

19 Nov 2018 - Times Top10<ref>{{cite news| title = 'Faster than Bolt, on a different field'| url = https://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/india/timestopten/msid-66607947,card-66609215.cms| date = 19 Nov 2018 | work=Times Top10}}</ref>

pages.title: Prithveesh K. Bhat
pages.text:
{{Infobox person
| name          = Prithveesh K. Bhat
| image         = 
| alt           = <!-- descriptive text for use by speech synthesis (text-to-speech) software -->
| caption       = 
| birth_name    = <!-- only use if different from name -->
| birth_date    = {{Birth date and age|1995|12|23|df=yes}}<ref name=":2"/> 
| birth_place   = [[Cherkady]],<ref name=":4">{{cite web |url=https://www.thehindu.com/news/national/karnataka/In-the-record-book-for-training-500-students-in-solving-Rubik%E2%80%99s-Cube-in-a-year/article14390668.ece |title=In the record book for training 500 students in solving Rubik’s Cube in a year |website=thehindu.com |publisher=[[The Hindu]] |date=8 June 2016 |access-date=28 November 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181202082744/https://www.thehindu.com/news/national/karnataka/In-the-record-book-for-training-500-students-in-solving-Rubik%E2%80%99s-Cube-in-a-year/article14390668.ece |archive-date=2 December 2018 |dead-url=no |df=dmy-all }}</ref> [[Udupi district]], Karnataka, India
| nationality   = Indian
| other_names   = 
| occupation    = 
| years_active  = 2013 - present<ref name=":2"/>
| known_for     = Rubik's Cube solving and mosaic design
| notable_works = ''Rubik Magic'' (book)<ref name=":2"/>
| website = {{url|http://prithvimosaics.com/}}
}}
'''Prithveesh K. Bhat''' or '''Prathvish K. Bhat''' (born 23 December 1995) is an Indian [[Rubik's Cube]] [[Speedcubing|speedcuber]] and [[mosaic]] artist.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/mangaluru/Students-eye-world-record-with-4000-Rubiks-Cubes/articleshow/54476281.cms |title=Students eye world record with 4,000 Rubik's Cubes |website=timesofindia.indiatimes.com |publisher=[[The Times of India]] |date=23 September 2016 |access-date=2018-11-28 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170420111602/http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/mangaluru/Students-eye-world-record-with-4000-Rubiks-Cubes/articleshow/54476281.cms |archive-date=2017-04-20 |dead-url=no |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/mangaluru/guinness-recognises-efforts-by-sdmit-cubers-for-largest-dual-side-rubiks-cube-mosaic/articleshow/57236803.cms |title=Guinness recognises efforts by SDMIT Cubers for largest dual side Rubik's cube mosaic |website=timesofindia.indiatimes.com |publisher=[[The Times of India]] |date=19 February 2017 |access-date=2018-11-28 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181129095144/https://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/mangaluru/guinness-recognises-efforts-by-sdmit-cubers-for-largest-dual-side-rubiks-cube-mosaic/articleshow/57236803.cms |archive-date=2018-11-29 |dead-url=no |df= }}</ref> He has set several Rubik's Cube records, including two [[Guinness Book of World Records|Guinness World Record]]s namely ''′Largest Dual Sided Rubik’s Cube Mosaic′'', leading a team of 20 members<ref name=":1">{{cite web |url=https://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/mangaluru/chaplin-mr-beans-rubiks-cube-mosaic-creates-record/articleshow/57259451.cms |title=Chaplin, Mr Beans’ Rubik’s cube mosaic creates record |website=timesofindia.indiatimes.com |publisher=[[The Times of India]] |date=21 February 2017 |access-date=2018-11-28 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170226213240/http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/mangaluru/chaplin-mr-beans-rubiks-cube-mosaic-creates-record/articleshow/57259451.cms |archive-date=2017-02-26 |dead-url=no |df= }}</ref><ref name=":2">{{cite web |url=https://www.mangalorean.com/guinness-record-holder-prithvish-k-creates-worlds-1st-rubik-cube-ganesh-idol/ |title=Guinness Record Holder Prithvish K Creates World’s 1st Rubik Cube ‘Ganesh Idol’ |website=mangalorean.com |publisher=Mangalorean |date=28 August 2017 |access-date=2018-11-28 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180422185236/http://www.mangalorean.com/guinness-record-holder-prithvish-k-creates-worlds-1st-rubik-cube-ganesh-idol |archive-date=2018-04-22 |dead-url=no |df= }}</ref> and ''′Most contributions to a Rubik's cube mosaic′'', leading a team of 293 people.<ref name="GWR">{{Cite web |url=https://www.guinnessworldrecords.com/world-records/429429-most-contributions-to-a-rubiks-cube-mosaic |title=Most contributions to a Rubik's cube mosaic |website=Guinness World Records |publisher=[[Guinness World Records]] |location=Great Britain |publication-place=Great Britain |access-date=2019-06-14 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161105223436/http://www.guinnessworldrecords.com/world-records/429429-most-contributions-to-a-rubiks-cube-mosaic |archive-date=2016-11-05 |dead-url=no }}</ref>

He started pixel painting works to represent the same pixels over the graph sheet to create portraits which could be framed permanently.<ref name="DH1">{{Cite web |url=https://www.deccanherald.com/metrolife/portraits-rubik-s-cubes-717700.html |title=Portraits from Rubik’s cubes |author=Rakshitha M N, DH News Service, Bengaluru |date=10 February 2019 |website=Deccan Herald |publisher=[[Deccan Herald]] |location=Bangalore, Karnataka, India |language=en |publication-place=Bangalore, Karnataka, India |access-date=2019-02-11 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190212011315/https://www.deccanherald.com/metrolife/portraits-rubik-s-cubes-717700.html |archive-date=12 February 2019 |dead-url=no |df=dmy-all }}</ref>

In 2015, he wrote a book named ''′Rubik Magic′'', which consisted of a set of easy memorizing formulas for children to solve the Rubik Cube.<ref name=":3"/> It was released by [[Veerendra Heggade|D. Veerendra Heggade]].<ref name=":3"/> He solves Rubik's cube in 38 seconds<ref name=":3"/> and till date has taught over 3,500 children<ref name="DH1"/> and is conducting free workshops in many educational institutions.<ref name=":5"/>

==Personal life==
Prithveesh K. Bhat was born on 23 December 1995 to K. Shyam Prasad and Prasanna Prasad, both residents of Pethri, [[Udupi]].<ref name=":2"/> He has a younger brother named Pradheesh K. Prithveesh is currently studying [[Master of Engineering]] in [[Manipal Academy of Higher Education#Organisation|School of Information Sciences, Manipal]].<ref name=":2"/>

==Achievements==
On 2 October 2016 at Indraprastha Indoor stadium, [[Ujire]], he and his team ''′SDMIT Cubers′'' of 20 members created a vertical Rubik's cube mosaic wall, which on one side portrayed the picture of [[Mr. Bean]] and [[Charlie Chaplin]] on another.<ref name=":1"/><ref name=":2"/> The mosaic wall consisted of 4500 3x3x3 cubes, measured 14.981 sqm, stood approx. 15 feet tall and 10 feet wide, and was built in 7 hours. The expenses were entirely funded by Veerendra Heggade. It was listed in the [[Guinness Book of World Records]] as ''′Largest Dual Sided Rubik’s Cube Mosaic′''.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.thehindu.com/news/national/karnataka/Guinness-record-for-SDMIT%E2%80%99s-Rubik%E2%80%99s-Cube-mosaic-builders/article17348876.ece |title=Guinness record for SDMIT’s Rubik’s Cube mosaic builders |website=thehindu.com |publisher=[[The Hindu]] |date=23 February 2017 |access-date=28 November 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181202082744/https://www.thehindu.com/news/national/karnataka/Guinness-record-for-SDMIT%E2%80%99s-Rubik%E2%80%99s-Cube-mosaic-builders/article17348876.ece |archive-date=2 December 2018 |dead-url=no |df=dmy-all }}</ref>

On 5 May 2019, at Gopalan Innovation Mall, Bannerghatta road, Bangalore, Prithveesh lead a team of 293 people to create a portrait of a tiger, consisting of 1200 Rubik's cubes, to support the cause of tiger conservation in India.<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.thehindu.com/todays-paper/tp-national/tp-andhrapradesh/a-puzzle-and-a-message/article27043122.ece |title=A puzzle and a message |date=2019-05-06 |website=The Hindu |publisher=[[The Hindu]] |location=Andra Pradesh, India |publication-place=Andra Pradesh, India |access-date=2019-05-09}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.deccanherald.com/city/rubik-s-cube-tiger-portrait-a-world-record-732389.html |title=Rubik’s Cube tiger portrait a world record |date=2019-05-06 |website=Deccan Herald |publisher=[[Deccan Herald]] |location=Karnataka |publication-place=Karnataka |access-date=2019-05-09}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |url=https://kpepaper.asianetnews.com/2141603/Bengaluru/06052019#page/3/1 |title=Kannada Prabha Bengaluru epaper dated Mon, 6 May 19 |website=kpepaper.asianetnews.com |publisher=[[Kannada Prabha]], [[Asianet News]] |location=Bangalore, Karnataka, India |publication-place=Bangalore, Karnataka, India |access-date=2019-05-09}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |url=https://d14nckxhjt6h6p.cloudfront.net/Uv/2019/05/06/MAN/Manipal/MEDN/5_05/87b750585844d44b_05_hr.jpg |title=Udayavani / ePaper / Manipal edition / 6 May 2019 |website=epaper.udayavani.com |publisher=[[Udayavani]] |location=Manipal, Karnataka |publication-place=Manipal, Karnataka}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |url=https://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/mangaluru/293-cubers-from-karnataka-all-set-to-enter-guinness-record/articleshow/69293464.cms |title=293 cubers from Karnataka all set to enter Guinness Record /Mangaluru News - Times of India |last=May 12 |first=Vinobha K. T. /TNN |last2=2019 |website=The Times of India |publisher=[[The Times of India]] |location=India |publication-place=India |access-date=2019-05-16 |last3=Ist |first3=16:07}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |url=https://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/mangaluru/guinness-attempt-awaits-the-final-approval/articleshow/69298274.cms |title=Guinness World Record authorities attempt awaits the final approval /Mangaluru News - Times of India |website=The Times of India |publisher=[[The Times of India]] |location=India |publication-place=India |access-date=2019-05-18 }}</ref> It was listed in the [[Guinness Book of World Records]] as ''′Most contributions to a Rubik's cube mosaic′''.<ref name="GWR"/>

He received an honorary doctorate from World Records University<ref>{{cite web |url=http://worldrecordsuniversity.co.uk/ |title=World Records University - Home |website=worldrecordsuniversity.co.uk |publisher=World Records University |access-date=2018-11-28 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181105002817/http://worldrecordsuniversity.co.uk/ |archive-date=2018-11-05 |dead-url=no |df= }}</ref> ''(Regd. under [[Government of UK]])'' on March 5, 2017, in a convocation held in [[Haryana]].<ref name=":2"/>

Prithveesh holds a world record for ''′Dual-sided Rubik's Cube′'' listed in [[Limca Book of Records]],<ref>{{cite web |url=https://books.google.co.in/books?id=c79aDwAAQBAJ&pg=PT61&dq=prithveesh+k&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjvg4OHtvfeAhUBNo8KHeZJCA4Q6AEIKzAA#v=onepage&q=prithveesh%20k&f=false |title=Limca Book of Records: India at Her Best |website=books.google.co.in |publisher=[[Limca Book of Records]] |access-date=2018-11-28 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181128211123/https://books.google.co.in/books?id=c79aDwAAQBAJ&pg=PT61&dq=prithveesh+k&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjvg4OHtvfeAhUBNo8KHeZJCA4Q6AEIKzAA#v=onepage&q=prithveesh%20k&f=false#v=onepage&q=prithveesh%20k&f=false |archive-date=2018-11-28 |dead-url=no |df= }}</ref> and an Indian record listed in [[India Book of Records]] for ''′Most students trained in solving Rubik Cubes in a year′''.<ref name=":2"/><ref name=":3">{{cite web |url=https://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/mangaluru/Engg-student-trains-over-500-kids-to-solve-Rubik-Cube-enters-record-book/articleshow/52666428.cms |title=Engg student trains over 500 kids to solve Rubik Cube, enter record book |website=timesofindia.indiatimes.com |publisher=[[The Times of India]] |date=9 June 2016 |access-date=2018-11-28 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160610010112/http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/mangaluru/Engg-student-trains-over-500-kids-to-solve-Rubik-Cube-enters-record-book/articleshow/52666428.cms |archive-date=2016-06-10 |dead-url=no |df= }}</ref> He also holds a ''Assist World Record'', for creating a portrait of [[Abdul Kalam]] using 540 cubes.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.thehindu.com/news/national/tamil-nadu/Kalam%E2%80%99s-burial-site-agog-with-activities/article14512686.ece |title=Kalam’s burial site agog with activities |website=thehindu.com |publisher=[[The Hindu]] |date=28 July 2016 |access-date=28 November 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181202082744/https://www.thehindu.com/news/national/tamil-nadu/Kalam%E2%80%99s-burial-site-agog-with-activities/article14512686.ece |archive-date=2 December 2018 |dead-url=no |df=dmy-all }}</ref>

He ranked 3rd in state-level Rubik's Cube solving competition (non-[[World Cube Association|WCA]] event) held in Mangalore.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.thehindu.com/news/national/karnataka/youth-keen-to-popularise-rubiks-cube-in-rural-areas/article7472628.ece |title=Youth keen to popularise Rubik’s Cube in rural areas |website=thehindu.com |publisher=[[The Hindu]] |date=28 July 2015 |access-date=28 November 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181202082744/https://www.thehindu.com/news/national/karnataka/youth-keen-to-popularise-rubiks-cube-in-rural-areas/article7472628.ece |archive-date=2 December 2018 |dead-url=no |df=dmy-all }}</ref>

He has made over 70 portraits including those of Veerendra heggade, [[Narendra Modi]], [[A. P. J. Abdul Kalam]], [[Swami Vivekananda]], Mohan Alva, [[Ambareesh]], [[Yash (actor)|Yash]], [[Rakshit Shetty]], [[Sudeep]], [[Puneeth Rajkumar]], [[Sridevi]], [[Vishnuvardhan (actor)|Vishnuvardhan]], [[Mary Kom]], [[Darshan (actor)|Darshan]], and [[Yogaraj Bhat]] on various occasions in several locations in Karnataka and also in Hyderabad, Chennai and Uttar Pradesh.<ref name="DH1"/><ref name="VK"/><ref name="DH">{{Cite web |url=http://m.dailyhunt.in/news/india/kannada/balkani+news-epaper-balnews/rubiks+kyubnalli+aralitu+vikatakavi+yogaraaj+bhat+bhaavachitra-newsid-110630400?ss=wsp&s=pa |title=ರೂಬಿಕ್ಸ್ ಕ್ಯುಬ್ನಲ್ಲಿ ಅರಳಿತು ವಿಕಟಕವಿ ಯೋಗರಾಜ್ ಭಟ್ ಭಾವಚಿತ್ರ - Balkani News |date=8 March 2019  |website=Dailyhunt |publisher=[[Dailyhunt]] |location=Karnataka, India |language=kn |publication-place=Karnataka, India |access-date=2019-03-12}}</ref>

==Events==
*First [[Lord Ganesha]] [[Cult image|idol]] made out of Rubik Cubes, at the ''″My Friend Ganesha″'' ''(Idol making contest)'' held at Bharath Mall, [[Mangalore]] on 27 August 2017<ref name=":2"/>
*Created a 8×10 feet mosaic image of the [[Parliament of India]] using 1,950 Rubik's Cubes in seven hours,<ref name=":5">{{cite web |url=http://www.newindianexpress.com/cities/chennai/2018/jan/26/now-mosaic-magic-with-rubiks-cube-1763870.html |title=Now, mosaic magic with rubik’s cube |website=newindianexpress.com |publisher=[[New Indian Express]] |date=26 January 2018 |access-date=2018-11-28 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181128211057/http://www.newindianexpress.com/cities/chennai/2018/jan/26/now-mosaic-magic-with-rubiks-cube-1763870.html |archive-date=2018-11-28 |dead-url=no |df= }}</ref> on 26 January 2018.
*Created a 2×3 feet mosaic portrait of Anand C. Kunder using 540 cubes during event ''′Thangali-2′'', held at [[Shivarama Karantha]] Theme Park, [[Kota, Karnataka|Kota]], on 30 December 2018.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.vijaykarnatakaepaper.com/archive_2019-1-1_18_18_1_1_a.html |website=vijaykarnatakaepaper.com |title=Vijay Karnataka ''Namma Karavali'' |publisher=[[Vijaya Karnataka]] |date=1 January 2019 |access-date=3 January 2019 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190103161243/http://www.vijaykarnatakaepaper.com/archive_2019-1-1_18_18_1_1_a.html |archive-date=3 January 2019 |dead-url=no |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
*Participated and performed in ''India's Got Talent'' (Season 8).<ref name="DH1"/>
*Participated in [[Maruti Suzuki]] ''Colors of Youth'' (Season 7) in 2018.<ref name="VK">{{Cite web |url=https://vijaykarnataka.indiatimes.com/district/udupi/natasarvabhouma-movie-promo-rubiks-cube-prepared-by-pruthvish/articleshow/67913591.cms |title=ನಟ ಸಾರ್ವಭೌಮನಿಗೆ ರೂಬಿಕ್ಸ್ ಕ್ಯೂಬ್ ಪ್ರೊಮೊ |date=2019-02-09 |website=Vijaya Karnataka |publisher=[[Vijaya Karnataka]] |location=Bangalore, Karnataka |language=kn |publication-place=Bangalore, Karnataka |access-date=2019-02-11 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190212011826/https://vijaykarnataka.indiatimes.com/district/udupi/natasarvabhouma-movie-promo-rubiks-cube-prepared-by-pruthvish/articleshow/67913591.cms |archive-date=2019-02-12 |dead-url=no |df= }}</ref>
*Performed with his brother, in two episodes of [[SAB TV]]'s reality show ''[[India Ke Mast Kalandar]]'', which aired on 18 August<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.sonyliv.com/details/clips/5823808485001/-Twist-The-Rubix---India-Ke-Mast-Kalandar |title=Twist The Rubix - India Ke Mast Kalandar |year=2018 |website=www.sonyliv.com |publisher=[[Sony Liv]] |location=India |orig-year=2018 |access-date=2019-01-10}}</ref> and 16 September 2018.<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.sonyliv.com/details/clips/5835516934001/Joining-The-Pieces---India-Ke-Mast-Kalandar |title=Joining The Pieces - India Ke Mast Kalandar |year=2018 |website=www.sonyliv.com |publisher=[[Sony LIV]] |location=India |access-date=2019-01-10 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190110235028/https://www.sonyliv.com/details/clips/5835516934001/Joining-The-Pieces---India-Ke-Mast-Kalandar |archive-date=2019-01-10 |dead-url=no |df= }}</ref>
*Performed with his brother, in an episode of [[Colors Super]]'s reality show ''Majaa Bharatha'', which aired on 21 March 2017.<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.voot.com/shows/majaa-bharatha/1/475898/a-stand-up-special-by-mithra-and-roopika/483390 |title=Majaa Bharatha, A stand-up special by Mithra and Roopika, Episode 20 |last=TV |first=Colors |year=2017 |website=www.voot.com |publisher=[[Voot]], [[Colors Super]] |location=India |publication-place=India |access-date=2019-01-10}}</ref>
*Created Rubik's cube portrait of Puneeth Rajkumar, before the release of the movie [[Natasaarvabhowma]], on 5 February 2019.<ref name=":6">{{Cite web |url=https://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/entertainment/kannada/movies/news/puneeth-rajkumar-shares-portrait-made-out-of-rubiks-cubes/articleshow/67848867.cms |title=Puneeth Rajkumar shares portrait made out of Rubik’s Cubes - Times of India |year=2019 |website=The Times of India |publisher=[[The Times of India]] |location=India |language=en-IN |publication-place=India |publication-date=5 February 2019 |access-date=2019-02-09 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190209183235/https://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/entertainment/kannada/movies/news/puneeth-rajkumar-shares-portrait-made-out-of-rubiks-cubes/articleshow/67848867.cms |archive-date=9 February 2019 |dead-url=no |df=dmy-all }}</ref> The actor himself posted it in his [[Instagram]] profile, thanking the efforts of Prithveesh.<ref name=":6"/>
*Created Rubik's cube portrait of Yogaraj Bhat for his 2019 film [[Panchatantra (film)|Panchatantra]]. Bhat thanked the efforts of Prithveesh in his Instagram profile, on 8 March 2019.<ref name="DH"/>

pages.title: Macky Makisumi
pages.text:
{{BLP sources|date=September 2018}}
'''Shotaro Makisumi''' ({{lang-ja|Makisumi Shōtarō}}; commonly known as "'''Macky'''", born March 21, 1990 in [[Ube, Yamaguchi|Ube]], [[Yamaguchi Prefecture|Yamaguchi]], [[Japan]]), is best known for setting several world records for [[speedcubing]], or quickly solving the [[Rubik's Cube]].

Macky lived in [[Arcadia, California]], and graduated in the class of 2008 from [[Polytechnic School]] in [[Pasadena, California]]. In 2012, he graduated from [[Princeton University]], where he majored in mathematics. He completed his Ph.D. at [[Stanford University]] in 2017, and is now a Ritt Assistant Professor of mathematics at [[Columbia University]]. He has held seven world records with the [[World Cube Association]].

In addition to [[speedcubing]], he is involved in mathematics competitions and [[juggling]].

==Past Records held<ref>[http://www.worldcubeassociation.org/results/p.php?i=2003MAKI01 World Cube Association records of Makisumi's official solving times]</ref>==

===World Records===
*2x2x2 Speedsolve: 4.13 seconds single; 6.29 seconds average of 5
*3x3x3 Speedsolve: 12.11 seconds single; 14.52 seconds average of 5
*3x3x3 Blindfolded: 2 minutes 18.52 seconds
*3x3x3 One-handed: 23.76 seconds single; 27.56 seconds average of 3

===Asian Records===
*4x4x4 Speedsolve: 1:14.55 seconds single; 1:16.39 seconds average of 3

pages.title: Yu Nakajima
pages.text:
{{nihongo|'''Yu Nakajima'''|中島 悠|extra=born February 15, 1991 in [[Ebetsu, Hokkaidō]]}} is a Japanese [[Rubik's Cube]] solver.<ref>{{cite web|title=Rubik's Cube Solver|url=https://rubiks-cube-solver.com/|publisher=www.rubiks-cube-solver.com|accessdate=21 June 2016}}</ref>

Yu held the former [[world record]] for Rubik's Cube average (11.28 seconds) and single (8.72 seconds).<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.worldcubeassociation.org/results/p.php?i=2007NAKA03|title=Official results of Yu Nakajima. |accessdate=2008-05-21|work=worldcubeassociation.org}}</ref> He beat the previous world record holder [[Edouard Chambon]], who had a single solve record of 9.18 seconds.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.worldcubeassociation.org/results/p.php?i=2004CHAM01|title=Official results of Edouard Chambon.|accessdate=2008-05-21|work=worldcubeassociation.org}}</ref> Both records were set on May 5, 2008, at the ''[[Kashiwa]] Open 2008''. On May 23, 2008 Yu posted a video on [[YouTube]] where he completed the cube in 6.57 seconds.<ref>[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=jI_zjWssn2g&feature=channel_page Rubik's Cube: 6.57 seconds] - nakaji1084 May 23, 2008</ref> He also solved the Rubik's magic in 1.05 seconds. He set the World Record for the [[5x5x5]] cube at 54.86 seconds in April 2012.

pages.title: Lars Petrus
pages.text:
{{refimproveBLP|date=January 2011}}
'''Lars Erik Petrus''' (born 4 November 1960 in [[Luleå]] in Sweden) is an accomplished [[Speedcubing|speedcuber]].

In 1982, he became the national champion of [[Sweden]], and went on to finish fourth overall at the first official [[Rubik's Cube]] World Championships held in [[Budapest]], [[Hungary]]. He later published his method, known as the Petrus system, on the Internet. It became a fairly popular method among intermediate and upper-level speedcubers, although its more recent use has diminished considerably due to the increased predominance of methods such as ZZ, Roux, and CFOP. Petrus won the 3x3x3 Fewest Moves category at the 2005 World Championships held in November 2005 at [[Lake Buena Vista]], [[Florida]], USA claiming the US$500 prize. He currently (since 1995) resides in [[SF Bay Area]], [[California]], USA.

==The Lars Petrus System==
The Petrus System was designed as an alternative to the popular layer-based solutions of the early 1980s. Petrus reasoned that as a solver constructs layers, further organization of the cube's remaining pieces is restricted by what one has already done. In order for a layer-based solution to continue after the first layer had been constructed, the solved portion of the cube would have to be temporarily disassembled while the desired moves were made, then reassembled afterwards. Petrus sought to get around this quagmire by solving the cube outwards from one corner, leaving him with unrestricted movement on several sides of the cube as he progressed. This method is often used to solve the cube in a fewest-moves solution.

===The Method===
The system uses seven basic steps to solve a Rubik's Cube.

# Build a 2x2x2 block
# Expand to a 2x2x3 without destroying the 2x2x2 block
# Correct edge orientation
# Solve two complete layers
# Permute the remaining corners
# Orient the remaining corners
# Permute the final edges

Petrus invented three simple and flexible algorithms to complete the last three steps, which he named Niklas, Sune and Allan. 

While the method stands alone as an efficient system for solving the Rubik's Cube, many modifications have been made over the years to stay on the cutting edge of competitive [[speedcubing]]. Many more algorithms have been added to shave seconds off the solution time, and steps 5+6 or 6+7 are often combined depending on the problems each case presents. Petrus' personal best speedsolve is 13.6 seconds, achieved in 2006.

==External links==
*[http://www.rubiks.com/lvl4/commun/cbeclb/wc2005/results.html Rubik's World Championship 2005] - Official Results

*[http://www.worldcubeassociation.org/results/p.php?i=1982PETR01 Lars's Official Records] - From the [[World Cube Association]] website

pages.title: Simon Westlund
Kepler–Poinsot polyhedron
pages.text:
{{multiple image | align = right | perrow = 2 | total_width = 320 | image1 = Great dodecahedron (gray with yellow face).svg | caption1 = [[Great dodecahedron]] | image2 = Small stellated dodecahedron (gray with yellow face).svg | caption2 = [[Small stellated dodecahedron]] | image3 = Great icosahedron (gray with yellow face).svg | caption3 = [[Great icosahedron]] | image4 = Great stellated dodecahedron (gray with yellow face).svg | caption4 = [[Great stellated dodecahedron]] }} In [[geometry]], a '''Kepler–Poinsot polyhedron''' is any of four [[Regular polyhedron|regular]] [[Star polyhedron|star polyhedra]].Coxeter, ''Star polytopes and the Schläfli function f(α,β,γ)'' p. 121 1. The Kepler–Poinsot polyhedra They may be obtained by [[stellation|stellating]] the regular [[Convex polyhedron|convex]] [[dodecahedron]] and [[icosahedron]], and differ from these in having regular [[pentagram]]mic [[face (geometry)|face]]s or [[vertex figure]]s. They can all be seen as three-dimensional analogues of the pentagram in one way or another. == Characteristics == === Non-convexity === These figures have [[pentagram]]s (star pentagons) as faces or vertex figures. The small and [[great stellated dodecahedron]] have [[star polygon|nonconvex regular]] [[pentagram]] faces. The [[great dodecahedron]] and [[great icosahedron]] have [[convex polygon|convex]] polygonal faces, but pentagrammic [[vertex figure]]s. In all cases, two faces can intersect along a line that is not an edge of either face, so that part of each face passes through the interior of the figure. Such lines of intersection are not part of the polyhedral structure and are sometimes called false edges. Likewise where three such lines intersect at a point that is not a corner of any face, these points are false vertices. The images below show spheres at the true vertices, and blue rods along the true edges. For example, the [[small stellated dodecahedron]] has 12 [[pentagram]] faces with the central [[pentagon]]al part hidden inside the solid. The visible parts of each face comprise five [[isosceles triangle]]s which touch at five points around the pentagon. We could treat these triangles as 60 separate faces to obtain a new, irregular polyhedron which looks outwardly identical. Each edge would now be divided into three shorter edges (of two different kinds), and the 20 false vertices would become true ones, so that we have a total of 32 vertices (again of two kinds). The hidden inner pentagons are no longer part of the polyhedral surface, and can disappear. Now [[Planar graph#Euler's formula|Euler's formula]] holds: 60 − 90 + 32 = 2. However this polyhedron is no longer the one described by the [[Schläfli symbol]] {5/2, 5}, and so can not be a Kepler–Poinsot solid even though it still looks like one from outside. === Euler characteristic χ === A Kepler–Poinsot polyhedron covers its circumscribed sphere more than once, with the centers of faces acting as winding points in the figures which have pentagrammic faces, and the vertices in the others. Because of this, they are not necessarily topologically equivalent to the sphere as Platonic solids are, and in particular the [[Euler characteristic|Euler relation]] :\chi=V-E+F=2\ does not always hold. Schläfli held that all polyhedra must have χ = 2, and he rejected the small stellated dodecahedron and great dodecahedron as proper polyhedra. This view was never widely held. A modified form of Euler's formula, using [[Density (polytope)|density]] (''D'') of the [[vertex figure]]s (d_v) and faces (d_f) was given by [[Arthur Cayley]], and holds both for convex polyhedra (where the correction factors are all 1), and the Kepler–Poinsot polyhedra: :d_v V - E + d_f F = 2D. === Duality and Petrie polygons === The Kepler–Poinsot polyhedra exist in [[dual polyhedron|dual]] pairs. Duals have the same [[Petrie polygon]], or more precisely, Petrie polygons with the same two dimensional projection. The following images show the two [[dual compound]]s with the same [[midsphere|edge radius]]. They also show that the Petrie polygons are [[skew polygon|skew]]. Two relationships described in the article below are also easily seen in the images: That the violet edges are the same, and that the green faces lie in the same planes. {| class="wikitable" ! horizontal edge in front ! vertical edge in front ! Petrie polygon |- | [[small stellated dodecahedron]] {5/2, 5} | [[great dodecahedron]] {5, 5/2} | [[Regular hexagon|hexagon]] {6} |- | [[great icosahedron]] {3, 5/2} | [[great stellated dodecahedron]] {5/2, 3} | [[Decagram (geometry)|decagram]] {10/3} |} {| style="width: 100%;" |- | {{multiple image | align = center | width = 200 | image1 = Skeleton pair Gr12 and dual, size s.png | image2 = Skeleton pair Gr12 and dual, Petrie, stick, size s.png | image3 = Skeleton pair Gr12 and dual, Petrie, stick, size s, 3-fold.png | footer = [[Compound of small stellated dodecahedron and great dodecahedron|Compound of sD and gD]] with Petrie hexagons   ([[:File:Skeleton St12, size s.png|sD]] and [[:File:Skeleton Gr12, size s.png|gD]] alone) }} | {{multiple image | align = center | width = 200 | image1 = Skeleton pair Gr20 and dual, size s.png | image2 = Skeleton pair Gr20 and dual, Petrie, stick, size s.png | image3 = Skeleton pair Gr20 and dual, Petrie, stick, size s, 5-fold.png | footer = [[Compound of great icosahedron and great stellated dodecahedron|Compound of gI and gsD]] with Petrie decagrams   ([[:File:Skeleton Gr20, size s.png|gI]] and [[:File:Skeleton GrSt12, size s.png|gsD]] alone) }} |} === Summary === {| class="wikitable" |- !Name
