pages.title: Elongated pentagonal pyramid
pages.text:
{{Infobox polyhedron |image=elongated_pentagonal_pyramid.png |type=[[Johnson solid|Johnson]]
[[elongated square pyramid|J8]] - '''J9''' - [[gyroelongated square pyramid|J10]] |faces=5 [[triangle]]s
5 [[Square (geometry)|square]]s
1 [[pentagon]] |edges=20 |vertices=11 |symmetry=[[cyclic symmetries|''C''5v]], [5], (*55) |rotation_group=''C''5, [5]+, (55) |vertex_config=5(42.5)
5(32.42)
1(35) |dual=self |properties=[[convex set|convex]] |net=Elongated_Pentagonal_Pyramid_Net.svg }} In [[geometry]], the '''elongated pentagonal pyramid''' is one of the [[Johnson solid]]s (''J''9). As the name suggests, it can be constructed by elongating a [[pentagonal pyramid]] (''J''2) by attaching a [[pentagonal prism]] to its base. {{Johnson solid}} == Dual polyhedron == The dual of the elongated pentagonal pyramid has 11 faces: 5 triangular, 1 pentagonal and 5 trapezoidal. {| class=wikitable width=320 |- valign=top !Dual elongated pentagonal pyramid !Net of dual |- valign=top |[[File:Dual elongated pentagonal pyramid.png|160px]] |[[File:Dual elongated pentagonal pyramid net.png|160px]] |} == See also == * [[Elongated pentagonal bipyramid]] ==External links== * {{mathworld2 | urlname2 = ElongatedPentagonalPyramid | title2 = Elongated pentagonal pyramid | urlname = JohnsonSolid | title = Johnson solid}} {{Johnson solids navigator}} [[Category:Johnson solids]] [[Category:Self-dual polyhedra]] [[Category:Pyramids and bipyramids]] {{Polyhedron-stub}}

pages.title: Elongated pentagonal rotunda
pages.text:
{{Infobox polyhedron |image=elongated_pentagonal_rotunda.png |type=[[Johnson solid|Johnson]]
[[elongated pentagonal cupola|''J''20]] -''' J21''' - [[gyroelongated triangular cupola|J22]] |faces=2x5 [[triangle]]s
2x5 [[Square (geometry)|square]]s
1+5 [[pentagon]]s
1 [[decagon]] |edges=55 |vertices=30 |symmetry=''C''5v| |vertex_config=10(42.10)
10(3.42.5)
2.5(3.5.3.5) |dual=- |properties=[[convex set|convex]] |net=Johnson solid 21 net.png }} In [[geometry]], the '''elongated pentagonal rotunda''' is one of the [[Johnson solid]]s (''J''21). As the name suggests, it can be constructed by elongating a [[pentagonal rotunda]] (''J''6) by attaching a [[decagonal prism]] to its base. It can also be seen as an [[elongated pentagonal orthobirotunda]] (''J''42) with one pentagonal rotunda removed. {{Johnson solid}} ==Formulae== The following [[formula]]e for [[volume]] and [[surface area]] can be used if all [[face (geometry)|faces]] are [[regular polygon|regular]], with edge length ''a'':[[Stephen Wolfram]], "[http://www.wolframalpha.com/input/?i=Elongated+pentagonal+rotunda Elongated pentagonal rotunda]" from [[Wolfram Alpha]]. Retrieved July 22, 2010. V=\frac{1}{12}(45+17\sqrt{5}+30\sqrt{5+2\sqrt{5}})a^3\approx14.612...a^3 A=\frac{1}{2}(20+\sqrt{5(145+58\sqrt{5}+2\sqrt{30(65+29\sqrt{5})})})a^2\approx32.3472...a^2 === Dual polyhedron === The dual of the elongated pentagonal rotunda has 30 faces: 10 isosceles triangles, 10 rhombi, and 10 quadrilaterals. {| class=wikitable width=320 |- valign=top !Dual elongated pentagonal rotunda !Net of dual |- valign=top |[[File:Dual elongated pentagonal rotunda.png|160px]] |[[File:Dual elongated pentagonal rotunda net.png|160px]] |} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * {{mathworld2 | urlname2 = JohnsonSolid | title2 = Johnson solid| urlname =ElongatedPentagonalRotunda| title = Elongated pentagonal rotunda}} {{Polyhedron-stub}} {{Johnson solids navigator}} [[Category:Johnson solids]]

pages.title: Elongated square bipyramid
pages.text:
{{Infobox polyhedron |image=elongated_square_dipyramid.png |type=[[Johnson solid|Johnson]]
[[elongated triangular bipyramid|J14]] - '''J15''' - [[elongated pentagonal bipyramid|J16]] |faces=8 [[triangle]]s
4 [[Square (geometry)|square]]s |edges=20 |vertices=10 |symmetry=[[Dihedral symmetry|''D''4h]], [4,2], (*422) |rotation_group=''D''4, [4,2]+, (422) |vertex_config=2(34)
8(32.42) |dual=[[Square bifrustum]] |properties=[[convex set|convex]] |net=Johnson solid 15 net.png }} In [[geometry]], the '''elongated square bipyramid''' (or '''elongated octahedron''') is one of the [[Johnson solid]]s (''J''15). As the name suggests, it can be constructed by elongating an [[octahedron]] by inserting a [[cube (geometry)|cube]] between its congruent halves. It has been named the '''pencil cube''' or '''12-faced pencil cube''' due to its shape.Order in Space: A design source book, Keith Critchlow, p.46-47Goldberg, Michael, ''On the space-filling octahedra'', Geometriae Dedicata, January 1981, Volume 10, Issue 1, pp 323–335 [https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/BF01447431] [http://documents.mx/documents/on-the-space-filling-octahedra.html PDF] {{Johnson solid}} A [[zircon]] crystal is an example of an elongated square bipyramid. == Dual polyhedron == The dual of the elongated square bipyramid is called a [[square bifrustum]] and has 10 faces: 8 trapezoidal and 2 square. {| class=wikitable width=320 |- valign=top !Dual elongated square bipyramid !Net of dual |- valign=top |[[File:Dual elongated square dipyramid.png|160px]] |[[File:Dual elongated square dipyramid net.png|160px]] |} == Related polyhedra and honeycombs == A special kind of elongated square bipyramid ''without'' all regular faces allows a self-tessellation of Euclidean space. The triangles of this elongated square bipyramid are ''not'' regular; they have edges in the ratio 2:{{radic|3}}:{{radic|3}}. :[[File:Elongated oblate octahedron.png|100px]][[File:Elongated oblate octahedron net.png|185px]] It can be considered a transitional phase between the [[cubic honeycomb|cubic]] and [[rhombic dodecahedral honeycomb]]s. The cells are here colored white, red, and blue based on their orientation in space. The [[square pyramid]] ''caps'' have shortened isosceles triangle faces, with six of these pyramids meeting together to form a cube. Cross-sections of the honeycomb, through cell centers produces a [[chamfered square tiling]], with flattened horizonal and vertical hexagons, and squares on the perpendicular polyhedra. {| class=wikitable |[[File:HC-J15.png|160px]]
Honeycomb |[[File:Elongated oblate octahedron-red-green-blue-honeycomb.png|200px]]
Half honeycomb |[[File:Elongated square tiling.svg|160px]]
[[Chamfered square tiling]] |} With regular faces, the elongated square bipyramid can form a [[tessellation of space]] with [[Tetrahedron|tetrahedra]] and [[Octahedron|octahedra]]. (The octahedra can be further decomposed into [[square pyramid]]s.){{Cite web | url=http://woodenpolyhedra.web.fc2.com/J15.html | title=J15 honeycomb}} This honeycomb can be considered an elongated version of the [[tetrahedral-octahedral honeycomb]]. == See also == *[[Elongated square pyramid]] ==References== {{Reflist}} == External links == * {{mathworld2 | urlname2 = JohnsonSolid | title2 = Johnson solid| urlname =ElongatedSquareDipyramid| title =Elongated square bipyramid}} {{Polyhedron-stub}} {{Johnson solids navigator}} [[Category:Johnson solids]] [[Category:Pyramids and bipyramids]]

pages.title: Elongated square cupola
pages.text:
{{Infobox polyhedron |image=elongated_square_cupola.png |type=[[Johnson solid|Johnson]]
[[elongated triangular cupola|J18]] - '''J19''' - [[elongated pentagonal cupola|J20]] |faces=4 [[triangle]]s
3x4+1 [[Square (geometry)|square]]s
1 [[octagon]] |edges=36 |vertices=20 |symmetry=''C''4v| |vertex_config=8(42.8)
4+8(3.43) |dual=- |properties=[[convex set|convex]] |net=Johnson solid 19 net.png }} In [[geometry]], the '''elongated square cupola''' is one of the [[Johnson solid]]s (''J''19). As the name suggests, it can be constructed by elongating a [[square cupola]] (''J''4) by attaching an [[octagonal prism]] to its base. The solid can be seen as a [[rhombicuboctahedron]] with its "lid" (another [[square cupola]]) removed. {{Johnson solid}} ==Formulae== The following [[formula]]e for [[volume]], [[surface area]] and [[circumscribed sphere|circumradius]] can be used if all [[face (geometry)|faces]] are [[regular polygon|regular]], with edge length ''a'':[[Stephen Wolfram]], "[http://www.wolframalpha.com/input/?i=Elongated+square+cupola Elongated square cupola]" from [[Wolfram Alpha]]. Retrieved July 22, 2010. V=(3+\frac{8\sqrt{2}}{3})a^3\approx6.77124...a^3 A=(15+2\sqrt{2}+\sqrt{3})a^2\approx19.5605...a^2 C=(\frac{1}{2}\sqrt{5+2\sqrt{2}})a\approx1.39897...a === Dual polyhedron === The dual of the elongated square cupola has 20 faces: 8 isosceles triangles, 4 kites, 8 quadrilaterals. {| class=wikitable width=320 |- valign=top !Dual elongated square cupola !Net of dual |- valign=top |[[File:Dual elongated square cupola.png|160px]] |[[File:Dual elongated square cupola net.png|160px]] |} ==Related polyhedra and honeycombs== The elongated square cupola forms space-filling [[Honeycomb (geometry)|honeycomb]]s with [[Tetrahedron|tetrahedra]] and [[cube]]s; with cubes and [[Cuboctahedron|cuboctahedra]]; and with tetrahedra, [[elongated square pyramid]]s, and [[elongated square bipyramid]]s. (The latter two units can be decomposed into cubes and [[square pyramid]]s.)http://woodenpolyhedra.web.fc2.com/J19.html
==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * {{mathworld2 | urlname2 = JohnsonSolid | title2 = Johnson solid| urlname =ElongatedSquareCupola| title =Elongated square cupola}} {{Johnson solids navigator}} {{Polyhedron-stub}} [[Category:Johnson solids]]

pages.title: Elongated square gyrobicupola
pages.text:
{{Infobox polyhedron |image=elongated square gyrobicupola.png |type=[[Johnson solid|Johnson]]
[[elongated triangular gyrobicupola|''J''36]] -''' J37''' – [[elongated pentagonal orthobicupola|J38]] |faces=8 [[triangle]]s
18 [[Square (geometry)|squares]] |edges=48 |vertices=24 |symmetry=''D''4d |vertex_config=8+16(3.43) |dual=[[Pseudo-deltoidal icositetrahedron]] |properties=[[convex set|convex]], singular [[vertex figure]] |net=Johnson solid 37 net.png }}In [[geometry]], the '''elongated square gyrobicupola''' or '''pseudorhombicuboctahedron''' is one of the [[Johnson solid]]s (''J''37). It is not usually considered to be an [[Archimedean solid]], even though its faces consist of [[regular polygon]]s that meet in the same pattern at each of its vertices, because unlike the 13 Archimedean solids, it lacks a set of global symmetries that take every vertex to every other vertex (though [[Branko Grünbaum|Grünbaum]] has suggested it should be added to the traditional list of Archimedean solids as a 14th example). It strongly resembles, but should not be mistaken for, the [[small rhombicuboctahedron]], which '''is''' an Archimedean solid. This shape may have been discovered by [[Johannes Kepler]] in his enumeration of the Archimedean solids, but its first clear appearance in print appears to be the work of [[Duncan Sommerville]] in 1905.{{citation|first=D. M. Y.|last=Sommerville|authorlink=Duncan Sommerville|title=Semi-regular networks of the plane in absolute geometry|journal=Transactions of the Royal Society of Edinburgh|volume=41|year=1905|pages=725–747|doi=10.1017/s0080456800035560|url=https://zenodo.org/record/1428682}}. As cited by {{harvtxt|Grünbaum|2009}}. It was independently rediscovered by [[J. C. P. Miller]] by 1930 (by mistake while attempting to construct a model of the [[small rhombicuboctahedron]]{{citation|last=Rouse Ball|title=Mathematical recreations and essays|page=137|edition=11|year=1939|editor-last=Coxeter|editor-first=H. S. M. }}) and again by V. G. Ashkinuse in 1957.{{citation | last = Grünbaum | first = Branko | authorlink = Branko Grünbaum | doi = 10.4171/EM/120 | issue = 3 | journal = Elemente der Mathematik | mr = 2520469 | pages = 89–101 | title = An enduring error | url = https://digital.lib.washington.edu/dspace/bitstream/handle/1773/4592/An_enduring_error.pdf | volume = 64 | year = 2009}} Reprinted in {{cite book|title=The Best Writing on Mathematics 2010|editor-first=Mircea|editor-last=Pitici|publisher=Princeton University Press|year=2011|pages=18–31}}. {{Johnson solid}} == Construction and relation to the rhombicuboctahedron == As the name suggests, it can be constructed by elongating a [[square gyrobicupola]] (''J''29) and inserting an [[octagon]]al [[prism (geometry)|prism]] between its two halves. {| class="wikitable" |[[File:Small rhombicuboctahedron.png|120px]]
Rhombicuboctahedron |[[File:Exploded rhombicuboctahedron.png|120px]]
Exploded sections of
rhombicuboctahedron |[[File:Pseudorhombicuboctahedron.png|120px]]
Pseudo-rhombicuboctahedron |} The solid can also be seen as the result of twisting one of the [[square cupola]]e (''J''4) on a [[rhombicuboctahedron]] (one of the [[Archimedean solid]]s; a.k.a. the elongated square orthobicupola) by 45 degrees. It is therefore a '''gyrate rhombicuboctahedron'''. Its similarity to the rhombicuboctahedron gives it the alternative name '''pseudorhombicuboctahedron'''. It has occasionally been referred to as "the fourteenth Archimedean solid". This property does not carry over to its pentagonal-faced counterpart, the [[gyrate rhombicosidodecahedron]]. == Symmetry and classification == The pseudorhombicuboctahedron possesses D4d symmetry. It is locally vertex-regular – the arrangement of the four faces incident on any vertex is the same for all vertices; this is unique among the Johnson solids. However, the manner in which it is "twisted" gives it a distinct "equator" and two distinct "poles", which in turn divide its vertices into 8 "polar" vertices (4 per pole) and 16 "equatorial" vertices. It is therefore not [[vertex-transitive]], and consequently not usually considered to be one of the [[Archimedean solid]]s. With faces colored by its ''D''4d symmetry, it can look like this: {| class=wikitable !colspan=2|pseudorhombicuboctahedron ![[Pseudo-deltoidal icositetrahedron]]
([[Dual polyhedron|Dual]]) |- |[[File:Johnson solid 37 net.png|120px]]
[[Polyhedral net|net]] |[[File:Johnson solid 37.png|120px]] |[[File:Pseudo-strombic icositetrahedron.png|120px]] |} There are 8 (green) squares around its [[equator]], 4 (red) triangles and 4 (yellow) squares above and below, and one (blue) square on each pole. ==Related polyhedra and honeycombs== The elongated square gyrobicupola can form a space-filling [[Honeycomb (geometry)|honeycomb]] with the regular [[tetrahedron]], cube, and [[cuboctahedron]]. It can also form another honeycomb with the tetrahedron, [[square pyramid]] and various combinations of cubes, [[elongated square pyramid]]s, and [[elongated square bipyramid]]s.{{citation|url=http://woodenpolyhedra.web.fc2.com/J37.html|title=J37 honeycombs|accessdate=2016-03-21|work=Gallery of Wooden Polyhedra}}
[[File:Pseudo-great rhombicuboctahedron.png|120px|thumb|right|The [[pseudo great rhombicuboctahedron]]]] The [[pseudo great rhombicuboctahedron]] is a nonconvex analog of the pseudo rhombicuboctahedron, constructed in a similar way from the [[nonconvex great rhombicuboctahedron]]. ==In chemistry== The polyvanadate ion [[[vanadium|V]]18[[oxygen|O]]42]12− has a pseudorhombicuboctahedral structure, where each square face acts as the base of a VO5 pyramid.{{Greenwood&Earnshaw2nd|page=986}} == References == {{Reflist}} ==Further reading== * {{citation | author= Anthony Pugh | year= 1976 | title= Polyhedra: A visual approach | publisher= University of California Press Berkeley | location= California | isbn= 0-520-03056-7 }} Chapter 2: Archimedean polyhedra, prisma and antiprisms, p. 25 Pseudo-rhombicuboctahedron ==External links== * {{Mathworld2 | urlname = ElongatedSquareGyrobicupola | title = Elongated square gyrobicupola | urlname2 = JohnsonSolid | title2 = Johnson solid }} * [http://www.georgehart.com/virtual-polyhedra/pseudo-rhombicuboctahedra.html George Hart: pseudo-rhombicuboctahedra] {{Johnson solids navigator}} [[Category:Johnson solids]] [[Category:Pseudo-uniform polyhedra]]

pages.title: Elongated square pyramid
pages.text:
{{Infobox polyhedron |image=elongated_square_pyramid.png |type=[[Johnson solid|Johnson]]
[[elongated triangular pyramid|J7]] - '''J8''' - [[elongated pentagonal pyramid|J9]] |faces=4 [[triangle]]s
1+4 [[Square (geometry)|square]]s |edges=16 |vertices=9 |symmetry=[[cyclic symmetries|''C''4v]], [4], (*44) |rotation_group=''C''4, [4]+, (44) |vertex_config=4(43)
1(34)
4(32.42) |dual=self |properties=[[convex set|convex]] |net=Elongated_Square_Pyramid_Net.svg }} In [[geometry]], the '''elongated square pyramid''' is one of the [[Johnson solid]]s (''J''8). As the name suggests, it can be constructed by elongating a [[square pyramid]] (''J''1) by attaching a [[cube (geometry)|cube]] to its square base. Like any elongated [[pyramid]], it is topologically (but not geometrically) self-[[dual polyhedron|dual]]. {{Johnson solid}} == Dual polyhedron == The dual of the elongated square pyramid has 9 faces: 4 triangular, 1 square and 4 trapezoidal. {| class=wikitable width=320 |- valign=top !Dual elongated square pyramid !Net of dual |- valign=top |[[File:Dual elongated square pyramid.png|160px]] |[[File:Dual elongated square pyramid net.png|160px]] |} ==Related polyhedra and honeycombs== The elongated square pyramid can form a [[tessellation of space]] with [[Tetrahedron|tetrahedra]],http://woodenpolyhedra.web.fc2.com/J8.html similar to a modified [[tetrahedral-octahedral honeycomb]]. == See also== *[[Elongated square bipyramid]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * {{mathworld2 | urlname2 = ElongatedSquarePyramid | title2 = Elongated square pyramid| urlname = JohnsonSolid | title = Johnson solid}} {{Johnson solids navigator}} {{Polyhedron-stub}} [[Category:Johnson solids]] [[Category:Self-dual polyhedra]] [[Category:Pyramids and bipyramids]]

pages.title: Elongated triangular bipyramid
pages.text:
{{Infobox polyhedron |image=elongated_triangular_dipyramid.png |type=[[Johnson solid|Johnson]]
[[pentagonal bipyramid|''J''13]] -''' J14''' - [[elongated square bipyramid|J15]] |faces=6 [[triangle]]s
3 [[Square (geometry)|square]]s |edges=15 |vertices=8 |symmetry=[[Dihedral symmetry|''D''3h]], [3,2], (*322) |rotation_group=''D''3, [3,2]+, (322) |vertex_config=2(33)
6(32.42) |dual=[[Triangular bifrustum]] |properties=[[convex set|convex]] |net=Johnson solid 14 net.png }} In [[geometry]], the '''elongated triangular [[bipyramid]]''' (or '''dipyramid''') is one of the [[Johnson solid]]s (''J''14), [[convex polyhedron|convex polyhedra]] whose faces are [[regular polygon]]s. As the name suggests, it can be constructed by elongating a [[triangular bipyramid]] (''J''12) by inserting a [[triangular prism]] between its congruent halves. {{Johnson solid}} The [[nirrosula]], an African musical instrument woven out of strips of plant leaves, is made in the form of a series of elongated bipyramids with non-equilateral triangles as the faces of their end caps.{{citation|first=Paulus|last=Gerdes|title=Exploration of technologies, emerging from African cultural practices, in mathematics (teacher) education|journal=ZDM, the International Journal on Mathematics Education|volume=42|issue=1|pages=11–17|doi=10.1007/s11858-009-0208-2|year=2009}}. ==Formulae== The following [[formula]]e for [[volume]] and [[surface area]] can be used if all [[face (geometry)|faces]] are [[regular polygon|regular]], with edge length ''a'':[[Stephen Wolfram]], "[http://www.wolframalpha.com/input/?i=Elongated+triangular+dipyramid Elongated triangular dipyramid]" from [[Wolfram Alpha]]. Retrieved July 22, 2010. V=(\frac{1}{12}(2\sqrt{2}+3\sqrt{3}))a^3\approx0.668715...a^3 A=(\frac{3}{2}(2+\sqrt{3}))a^2\approx5.59808...a^2 === Dual polyhedron === The dual of the elongated triangular bipyramid is called a [[triangular bifrustum]] and has 8 faces: 6 trapezoidal and 2 triangular. {| class=wikitable width=320 |- valign=top !Dual elongated triangular bipyramid !Net of dual |- valign=top |[[File:Dual elongated triangular dipyramid.png|160px]] |[[File:Dual elongated triangular dipyramid net.png|160px]] |} ==References== {{Reflist}} == External links == * {{mathworld2 | urlname2 = JohnsonSolid | title2 = Johnson solid| urlname =ElongatedTriangularDipyramid| title =Elongated triangular bipyramid}} {{Johnson solids navigator}} {{Polyhedron-stub}} [[Category:Johnson solids]] [[Category:Pyramids and bipyramids]]

pages.title: Elongated triangular cupola
pages.text:
{{Infobox polyhedron |image=elongated_triangular_cupola.png |type=[[Johnson solid|Johnson]]
[[gyroelongated square bipyramid|J17]] - '''J18''' - [[elongated square cupola|J19]] |faces=1+3 [[triangle]]s
3x3 [[Square (geometry)|square]]s
1 [[hexagon]] |edges=27 |vertices=15 |symmetry=''C''3v| |vertex_config=6(42.6)
3(3.4.3.4)
6(3.43) |dual=- |properties=[[convex set|convex]] |net=Johnson solid 18 net.png }} In [[geometry]], the '''elongated triangular cupola''' is one of the [[Johnson solid]]s (''J''18). As the name suggests, it can be constructed by elongating a [[triangular cupola]] (''J''3) by attaching a [[hexagonal prism]] to its base. {{Johnson solid}} ==Formulae== The following [[formula]]e for [[volume]] and [[surface area]] can be used if all [[face (geometry)|faces]] are [[regular polygon|regular]], with edge length ''a'':[[Stephen Wolfram]], "[http://www.wolframalpha.com/input/?i=Elongated+triangular+cupola Elongated triangular cupola]" from [[Wolfram Alpha]]. Retrieved July 22, 2010. V=(\frac{1}{6}(5\sqrt{2}+9\sqrt{3}))a^3\approx3.77659...a^3 A=(9+\frac{5\sqrt{3}}{2})a^2\approx13.3301...a^2 === Dual polyhedron === The dual of the elongated triangular cupola has 15 faces: 6 isosceles triangles, 3 rhombi, and 6 quadrilaterals. {| class=wikitable width=320 |- valign=top !Dual elongated triangular cupola !Net of dual |- valign=top |[[File:Dual elongated triangular cupola.png|160px]] |[[File:Dual elongated triangular cupola net.png|160px]] |} ==Related polyhedra and honeycombs== The elongated triangular cupola can form a [[tessellation of space]] with [[Tetrahedron|tetrahedra]] and [[square pyramid]]s.http://woodenpolyhedra.web.fc2.com/J18.html ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * {{mathworld2 | urlname2 = JohnsonSolid | title2 = Johnson solid| urlname =ElongatedTriangularCupola| title =Elongated triangular cupola}} [[Category:Johnson solids]] {{Johnson solids navigator}} {{Polyhedron-stub}}

pages.title: Elongated triangular gyrobicupola
pages.text:
{{Infobox polyhedron |image=elongated triangular gyrobicupola.png |type=[[Johnson solid|Johnson]]
[[elongated triangular orthobicupola|''J''35]] -''' J36''' - [[elongated square gyrobicupola|J37]] |faces=2+6 [[triangle]]s
2x6 [[Square (geometry)|square]]s |edges=36 |vertices=18 |symmetry=''D''3d| |vertex_config=6(3.4.3.4)
12(3.43) |dual=- |properties=[[convex set|convex]] |net=Johnson solid 36 net.png }} In [[geometry]], the '''elongated triangular gyrobicupola''' is one of the [[Johnson solid]]s (''J''36). As the name suggests, it can be constructed by elongating a "triangular gyrobicupola," or [[cuboctahedron]], by inserting a [[hexagonal prism]] between its two halves, which are congruent [[triangular cupola]]e (''J''3). Rotating one of the cupolae through 60 degrees before the elongation yields the [[triangular orthobicupola]] (''J''35). {{Johnson solid}} ==Formulae== The following [[formula]]e for [[volume]] and [[surface area]] can be used if all [[faces (geometry)|faces]] are [[regular polygon|regular]], with edge length ''a'':[[Stephen Wolfram]], "[http://www.wolframalpha.com/input/?i=Elongated+triangular+gyrobicupola Elongated triangular gyrobicupola]" from [[Wolfram Alpha]]. Retrieved July 25, 2010. V=(\frac{5\sqrt{2}}{3}+\frac{3\sqrt{3}}{2})a^3\approx4.9551...a^3 A=2(6+\sqrt{3})a^2\approx15.4641...a^2 ==Related polyhedra and honeycombs== The elongated triangular gyrobicupola forms space-filling [[Honeycomb (geometry)|honeycomb]]s with [[Tetrahedron|tetrahedra]] and [[square pyramid]]s.http://woodenpolyhedra.web.fc2.com/J36.html
==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * {{MathWorld2|title2=Johnson solid|urlname2=JohnsonSolid| urlname=ElongatedTriangularGyrobicupola | title=Elongated triangular gyrobicupola}} {{Johnson solids navigator}} {{Polyhedron-stub}} [[Category:Johnson solids]]

pages.title: Elongated triangular orthobicupola
pages.text:
{{Infobox polyhedron |image=elongated triangular orthobicupola.png |type=[[Johnson solid|Johnson]]
[[pentagonal orthobirotunda|''J''34]] -''' J35''' - [[elongated triangular gyrobicupola|J36]] |faces=2+6 [[triangle]]s
2x3+6 [[Square (geometry)|square]]s |edges=36 |vertices=18 |symmetry=''D''3h| |vertex_config=6(3.4.3.4)
12(3.43) |dual=- |properties=[[convex set|convex]] |net=Johnson solid 35 net.png }} In [[geometry]], the '''elongated triangular orthobicupola''' is one of the [[Johnson solid]]s (''J''35). As the name suggests, it can be constructed by elongating a [[triangular orthobicupola]] (''J''27) by inserting a [[hexagon]]al [[prism (geometry)|prism]] between its two halves. The resulting solid is superficially similar to the [[rhombicuboctahedron]] (one of the [[Archimedean solid]]s), with the difference that it has threefold [[rotational symmetry]] about its axis instead of fourfold symmetry. {{Johnson solid}} == Volume == The volume of ''J''35 can be calculated as follows: ''J''35 consists of 2 cupolae and hexagonal prism. The two cupolae makes 1 cuboctahedron = 8 tetrahedra + 6 half-octahedra. 1 octahedron = 4 tetrahedra, so total we have 20 tetrahedra. What is the volume of a tetrahedron? Construct a tetrahedron having vertices in common with alternate vertices of a cube (of side \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}, if tetrahedron has unit edges). The 4 triangular pyramids left if the tetrahedron is removed from the cube form half an octahedron = 2 tetrahedra. So V_{tetrahedron} = \frac{1}{3} V_{cube} = \frac{1}{3} \frac{1}{{\sqrt{2}}^3} = \frac{\sqrt{2}}{12} The hexagonal prism is more straightforward. The hexagon has area 6 \frac{\sqrt{3}}{4}, so V_{prism} = \frac{3 \sqrt{3}}{2} Finally V_{J_{35}} = 20 V_{tetrahedron} + V_{prism} = \frac{5 \sqrt{2}}{3} + \frac{3 \sqrt{3}}{2} numerical value: V_{J_{35}} = 4.9550988153084743549606507192748 ==Related polyhedra and honeycombs== The elongated triangular orthobicupola forms space-filling [[Honeycomb (geometry)|honeycomb]]s with [[Tetrahedron|tetrahedra]] and [[square pyramid]]s.http://woodenpolyhedra.web.fc2.com/J35.html
==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * {{MathWorld2|title2=Johnson solid|urlname2=JohnsonSolid| urlname=ElongatedTriangularOrthobicupola | title=Elongated triangular orthobicupola}} {{Johnson solids navigator}} {{Polyhedron-stub}} [[Category:Johnson solids]]

pages.title: Elongated triangular pyramid
pages.text:
{{Infobox polyhedron | image = elongated_triangular_pyramid.png | type = [[Johnson solid|Johnson]]
[[pentagonal rotunda|J6]] -''' J7''' - [[elongated square pyramid|J8]] | faces = 1+3 [[triangle]]s
3 [[Square (geometry)|square]]s | edges = 12 | vertices = 7 | symmetry = ''C''3v, [3], (*33) | rotation_group = ''C''3, [3]+, (33) | vertex_config = 1(33)
3(3.42)
3(32.42) | dual = self | properties = [[convex set|convex]] | net = Elongated Triangular Pyramid Net.svg }} In [[geometry]], the '''elongated triangular pyramid''' is one of the [[Johnson solid]]s (''J''7). As the name suggests, it can be constructed by elongating a [[tetrahedron]] by attaching a [[triangular prism]] to its base. Like any elongated [[pyramid]], the resulting solid is topologically (but not geometrically) self-[[dual polyhedron|dual]]. {{Johnson solid}} ==Formulae== The following [[formula]]e for [[volume]] and [[surface area]] can be used if all [[face (geometry)|faces]] are [[regular polygon|regular]], with edge length ''a'':[[Stephen Wolfram]], "[http://www.wolframalpha.com/input/?i=Elongated+triangular+pyramid Elongated triangular pyramid]" from [[Wolfram Alpha]]. Retrieved July 21, 2010. V=(\frac{1}{12}(\sqrt{2}+3\sqrt{3}))a^3\approx0.550864...a^3 A=(3+\sqrt{3})a^2\approx4.73205...a^2 If the edges are not the same length, use the individual formulae for the tetrahedron and triangular prism separately, and add the results together. === Dual polyhedron === Topologically, the elongated triangular pyramid is its own dual. Geometrically, the dual has seven irregular faces: one equilateral triangle, three isosceles triangles and three isosceles trapezoids. {| class=wikitable width=320 |- valign=top !Dual elongated triangular pyramid !Net of dual |- valign=top |[[File:Dual elongated triangular pyramid.png|160px]] |[[File:Dual elongated triangular pyramid net.png|160px]] |} ==Related polyhedra and honeycombs== The elongated triangular pyramid can form a [[tessellation of space]] with [[square pyramid]]s and/or [[Octahedron|octahedra]].http://woodenpolyhedra.web.fc2.com/J7.html ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * {{mathworld2 | urlname2=ElongatedTriangularPyramid |title2=Elongated triangular pyramid| urlname=JohnsonSolid | title = Johnson solid}} {{Johnson solids navigator}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Elongated Triangular Pyramid}} [[Category:Johnson solids]] [[Category:Self-dual polyhedra]] [[Category:Pyramids and bipyramids]] {{Polyhedron-stub}}

pages.title: Gyrate bidiminished rhombicosidodecahedron
Gyrate rhombicosidodecahedron
pages.text:
{{Infobox polyhedron |image=gyrate_rhombicosidodecahedron.png |type=[[Johnson solid|Johnson]]
[[triaugmented truncated dodecahedron|J71]] - '''J72''' - [[parabigyrate rhombicosidodecahedron|J73]] |faces=4x5 [[triangle]]s
4x5+10 [[square (geometry)|square]]s
2+2x5 [[pentagon]]s |edges=120 |vertices=60 |symmetry=''C''5v |vertex_config=10(3.42.5)
4x5+3x10(3.4.5.4) |dual=- |properties=[[convex set|convex]] |net=Johnson solid 72 net.png }} In [[geometry]], the '''gyrate rhombicosidodecahedron''' is one of the [[Johnson solid]]s (''J''72). {{Johnson solid}} == Related polyhedron == It can be constructed as a [[rhombicosidodecahedron]] with one [[pentagonal cupola]] rotated through 36 degrees. They have the same faces around each vertex, but [[vertex configuration]]s along the rotation become a different order, ''3.4.4.5''. {| class=wikitable |[[File:Small rhombicosidodecahedron.png|160px]]
[[Rhombicosidodecahedron]] |[[File:Gyrate rhombicosidodecahedron color.png|160px]]
'''Gyrate rhombicosidodecahedron''' |} Alternative Johnson solids, constructed by rotating different cupolae of a rhombicosidodecahedron, are: the [[parabigyrate rhombicosidodecahedron]] (''J''73) where two opposing cupolae are rotated, the [[metabigyrate rhombicosidodecahedron]] (''J''74) where two non-opposing cupolae are rotated and the [[trigyrate rhombicosidodecahedron]] (''J''75) where three cupolae are rotated. ==External links== * {{Mathworld2 | urlname2 = JohnsonSolid | title2 = Johnson solid | urlname =GyrateRhombicosidodecahedron| title = Gyrate rhombicosidodecahedron}} [[Category:Johnson solids]] {{Johnson solids navigator}} {{Polyhedron-stub}}

pages.title: Gyrobifastigium
pages.text:
{{Infobox polyhedron |image=gyrobifastigium.png |type=[[Johnson solid|Johnson]]
[[gyroelongated pentagonal rotunda|''J''25]] -''' J26''' - [[triangular orthobicupola|J27]] |faces=4 [[triangle]]s
4 [[Square (geometry)|square]]s |edges=14 |vertices=8 |symmetry=''D''2d |vertex_config=4(3.42)
4(3.4.3.4) |dual=[[Elongated tetragonal disphenoid]] |properties=[[convex set|convex]], [[honeycomb]] |net=Johnson solid 26 net.png }} In [[geometry]], the '''gyrobifastigium''' is the 26th [[Johnson solid]] (''J''26). It can be constructed by joining two face-regular [[triangular prism]]s along corresponding square faces, giving a quarter-turn to one prism.{{citation|title=The Universal Book of Mathematics: From Abracadabra to Zeno's Paradoxes|first=David|last=Darling|authorlink=David J. Darling|publisher=John Wiley & Sons|year=2004|isbn=9780471667001|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=HrOxRdtYYaMC&pg=PA169|page=169}}. It is the only Johnson solid that can tile three-dimensional space. ==History and name== {{Johnson solid}} The name of the gyrobifastigium comes from the Latin ''fastigium'', meaning a sloping roof.{{citation|contribution-url=http://penelope.uchicago.edu/Thayer/E/Roman/Texts/secondary/SMIGRA*/Fastigium.html|editor-first=William|editor-last=Smith|editor-link=William Smith (lexicographer)|title=[[A Dictionary of Greek and Roman Antiquities]]|publisher=John Murray|location=London|year=1875|contribution=Fastigium|pages=523–524|first=Anthony|last=Rich}}. In the standard naming convention of the Johnson solids, ''bi-'' means two solids connected at their bases, and ''gyro-'' means the two halves are twisted with respect to each other. The gyrobifastigium's place in the list of Johnson solids, immediately before the [[bicupola (geometry)|bicupolas]], is explained by viewing it as a ''digonal gyrobicupola''. Just as the other regular cupolas have an alternating sequence of squares and triangles surrounding a single polygon at the top ([[triangular cupola|triangle]], [[square cupola|square]] or [[pentagonal cupola|pentagon]]), each half of the gyrobifastigium consists of just alternating squares and triangles, connected at the top only by a ridge. ==Honeycomb== The [[gyrated triangular prismatic honeycomb]] can be constructed by packing together large numbers of identical gyrobifastigiums. The gyrobifastigium is one of five convex polyhedra with regular faces capable of [[Space-filling polyhedron|space-filling]] (the others being the [[cube]], [[truncated octahedron]], [[triangular prism]], and [[hexagonal prism]]) and it is the only Johnson solid capable of doing so.{{citation | last1 = Alam | first1 = S. M. Nazrul | last2 = Haas | first2 = Zygmunt J. | contribution = Coverage and Connectivity in Three-dimensional Networks | doi = 10.1145/1161089.1161128 | isbn = 1-59593-286-0 | location = New York, NY, USA | pages = 346–357 | publisher = ACM | title = Proceedings of the 12th Annual International Conference on Mobile Computing and Networking (MobiCom '06) | year = 2006| arxiv = cs/0609069 }}.{{citation|title=The Six-Cornered Snowflake|first=Johannes|last=Kepler|authorlink=Johannes Kepler|publisher=Paul Dry Books|year=2010|isbn=9781589882850|at=Footnote 18, [https://books.google.com/books?id=yE8yTUFWLXgC&pg=PA146 p. 146]}}. [[File:Gyrobifastigium honeycomb.png|320px]] ==Formulae== The following [[formula]]e for [[volume]] and [[surface area]] can be used if all [[face (geometry)|faces]] are [[regular polygon|regular]], with edge length ''a'': :V=(\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2})a^3\approx0.866025...a^3 :A=(4+\sqrt{3})a^2\approx5.73205...a^2 == Topologically equivalent polyhedra== [[File:Rectified A2-antiprism.png|thumb|The gyrobifastigium topology exists in a [[tetragonal disphenoid]] with its lateral faces divided on the plane of symmetry which with specific proportions can [[Tetragonal disphenoid honeycomb|tessellate 3-space]].]] === Schmitt–Conway–Danzer biprism === [[File:SCD tile.svg|thumb|left|Schmitt–Conway–Danzer biprism]] The '''Schmitt–Conway–Danzer biprism''' (also called a SCD prototile[https://arxiv.org/pdf/1009.1419.pdf Forcing Nonperiodicity With a Single Tile] Joshua E. S. Socolar and Joan M. Taylor, 2011) is a polyhedron topologically equivalent to the gyrobifastigium, but with [[parallelogram]] and irregular triangle faces instead of squares and equilateral triangles. Like the gyrobifastigium, it can fill space, but only [[Aperiodic tiling|aperiodically]] or with a [[Screw axis|screw symmetry]], not with a full three-dimensional group of symmetries. Thus, it provides a partial solution to the three-dimensional [[einstein problem]].{{citation|title=Quasicrystals and Geometry|first=Marjorie|last=Senechal|authorlink=Marjorie Senechal|publisher=Cambridge University Press|year=1996|isbn=9780521575416|contribution=7.2 The SCD (Schmitt–Conway–Danzer) tile|pages=209–213|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=LdQ8AAAAIAAJ&pg=PA209}}.[http://demonstrations.wolfram.com/TilingSpaceWithASchmittConwayBiprism/ Tiling Space with a Schmitt-Conway Biprism] wolfram demonstrations {{-}} == Related polyhedra == [[File:Dual gyrobifastigium.png|thumb|Dual of gyrobifastigium]] The [[dual polyhedron]] of the gyrobifastigium has 8 faces: 4 [[isosceles triangle]]s, corresponding to the degree-three vertices of the gyrobifastigium, and 4 [[parallelogram]]s corresponding to the degree-four equatorial vertices. {{-}} === Elongated digonal gyrobicupola=== {{Also|Elongated gyrobifastigium}} The related ''elongated digonal gyrobicupola'' is formed by augmenting two [[triangular prism]]s to a central [[cube]]. The elongated digonal gyrobicupola can self-tessellate space. With regular faces, it has 4 sets of coplanar adjacent squares and triangles. The triangles and squares can be combined together as pentagons. {| class=wikitable |- align=center |[[File:Elongated digonal gyrobicupola.png|120px]]
elongated digonal gyrobicupola |} {{-}} === Bifastigium=== {{Also|Elongated octahedron}} {{Infobox polyhedron |image=4-diminished icosahedron.png |type= |faces=4 [[triangle]]s
4 [[trapezoid]]s |edges=14 |vertices=8 |symmetry=''D''2h |vertex_config= |dual=self-dual |properties=[[convex set|convex]] |net= }} The ''bifastigium'' (digonal ortho[[bicupola]]), is formed by gluing together two [[triangular prism]]s on their square faces, but without twisting. It is topologically a [[self-dual polyhedron]] and can also be called an ''elongated octahedron'' and ''self-dual octahedron''.http://dmccooey.com/polyhedra/SelfDualOctahedron2.html These polyhedra resemble the dual gyrobifastigium in that both shapes have eight vertices and eight faces, with the faces forming a belt of four quadrilaterals separating two pairs of triangles from each other. However, in the dual gyrobifastigium the two pairs of triangles are twisted with respect to each other while in the bifastigium they are not. It can be made with regular faces, squares and triangles, but the triangles will be coplanar. :[[File:Digonal orthobicupola.png|150px]] {{-}} ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * {{mathworld2 | urlname2 = JohnsonSolid | title2 = Johnson solid| | urlname = Gyrobifastigium | title = Gyrobifastigium}} {{Johnson solids navigator}} [[Category:Johnson solids]] [[Category:Space-filling polyhedra]]

pages.title: Gyroelongated pentagonal cupola
pages.text:
{{Infobox polyhedron |image=gyroelongated_pentagonal_cupola.png |type=[[Johnson solid|Johnson]]
[[gyroelongated square cupola|''J''23]] -''' J24''' - [[gyroelongated pentagonal rotunda|J25]] |faces=3x5+10 [[triangle]]s
5 [[Square (geometry)|square]]s
1 [[pentagon]]
1 [[decagon]] |edges=55 |vertices=25 |symmetry=''C''5v| |vertex_config=5(3.4.5.4)
2.5(33.10)
10(34.4) |dual=- |properties=[[convex set|convex]] |net=Johnson solid 24 net.png }} In [[geometry]], the '''gyroelongated pentagonal cupola''' is one of the [[Johnson solid]]s (''J''24). As the name suggests, it can be constructed by gyroelongating a [[pentagonal cupola]] (''J''5) by attaching a [[decagonal antiprism]] to its base. It can also be seen as a [[gyroelongated pentagonal bicupola]] (''J''46) with one pentagonal cupola removed. {{Johnson solid}} == Dual polyhedron == The dual of the gyroelongated pentagonal cupola has 25 faces: 10 kites, 5 rhombi, and 10 pentagons. {| class=wikitable width=320 |- valign=top !Dual gyroelongated pentagonal cupola !Net of dual |- valign=top |[[File:Dual gyroelongated pentagonal cupola.png|160px]] |[[File:Dual gyroelongated pentagonal cupola net.png|160px]] |} ==External links== * {{mathworld2 | urlname2 = JohnsonSolid | title2 = Johnson solid| urlname = GyroelongatedPentagonalCupola | title = Gyroelongated pentagonal cupola }} {{Polyhedron-stub}} {{Johnson solids navigator}} [[Category:Johnson solids]]

pages.title: Gyroelongated pentagonal pyramid
pages.text:
{{Infobox polyhedron |image=Blue gyroelongated pentagonal pyramid.svg |type=[[Johnson solid|Johnson]]
[[gyroelongated square pyramid|J10]] - '''J11''' - [[triangular dipyramid|J12]] |faces=3x5 [[triangle]]s
1 [[pentagon]] |edges=25 |vertices=11 |symmetry=[[cyclic symmetries|''C''5v]], [5], (*55) |rotation_group=''C''5, [5]+, (55) |vertex_config=5(33.5)
1+5(35) |dual=- |properties=[[convex set|convex]] |net=Gyroelongated pentagonal pyramid net.png }} In [[geometry]], the '''gyroelongated pentagonal pyramid''' is one of the [[Johnson solid]]s (''J''11). As its name suggests, it is formed by taking a [[pentagonal pyramid]] and "gyroelongating" it, which in this case involves joining a pentagonal [[antiprism]] to its base. {{Johnson solid}} It can also be seen as a '''diminished icosahedron''', an [[icosahedron]] with the top (a [[pentagonal pyramid]], ''J''2) chopped off by a plane. Other Johnson solids can be formed by cutting off multiple pentagonal pyramids from an icosahedron: the [[pentagonal antiprism]] and [[metabidiminished icosahedron]] (two pyramids removed), and the [[tridiminished icosahedron]] (three pyramids removed). == Dual polyhedron == The dual of the gyroelongated pentagonal pyramid has 11 faces: 5 kites, 1 regular pentagonal and 5 irregular pentagons. {| class=wikitable width=320 |- valign=top !Dual gyroelongated pentagonal pyramid !Net of dual |- valign=top |[[File:Dual gyroelongated pentagonal pyramid.png|160px]] |[[File:Dual gyroelongated pentagonal pyramid net.png|160px]] |} ==External links== * {{mathworld | urlname =GyroelongatedPentagonalPyramid| title =Gyroelongated pentagonal pyramid}} {{Johnson solids navigator}} [[Category:Johnson solids]] [[Category:Pyramids and bipyramids]] {{Polyhedron-stub}}

pages.title: Gyroelongated pentagonal rotunda
pages.text:
{{Infobox polyhedron |image=gyroelongated_pentagonal rotunda.png |type=[[Johnson solid|Johnson]]
[[gyroelongated pentagonal cupola|''J''24]] -''' J25''' - [[gyrobifastigium|J26]] |faces=4x5+10 [[triangle]]s
1+5 [[pentagon]]s
1 [[decagon]] |edges=65 |vertices=30 |symmetry=''C''5v| |vertex_config=2.5(3.5.3.5)
2.5(33.10)
10(34.5) |dual=- |properties=[[convex set|convex]] |net=Johnson solid 25 net.png }} In [[geometry]], the '''gyroelongated pentagonal rotunda''' is one of the [[Johnson solid]]s (''J''25). As the name suggests, it can be constructed by gyroelongating a [[pentagonal rotunda]] (''J''6) by attaching a [[decagonal antiprism]] to its base. It can also be seen as a [[gyroelongated pentagonal birotunda]] (''J''48) with one pentagonal rotunda removed. {{Johnson solid}} == Dual polyhedron == The dual of the gyroelongated pentagonal rotunda has 30 faces: 10 pentagons, 10 rhombi, and 10 quadrilaterals. {| class=wikitable width=320 |- valign=top !Dual gyroelongated pentagonal rotunda !Net of dual |- valign=top |[[File:Dual gyroelongated pentagonal rotunda.png|160px]] |[[File:Dual gyroelongated pentagonal rotunda net.png|160px]] |} ==External links== * {{mathworld2 | urlname2 = JohnsonSolid | title2 = Johnson solid| urlname = GyroelongatedPentagonalRotunda | title = Gyroelongated pentagonal rotunda }} {{Polyhedron-stub}} {{Johnson solids navigator}} [[Category:Johnson solids]]

pages.title: Gyroelongated square cupola
pages.text:
{{Infobox polyhedron |image=gyroelongated_square_cupola.png |type=[[Johnson solid|Johnson]]
[[gyroelongated triangular cupola|''J''22]] -''' J23''' - [[gyroelongated pentagonal cupola|J24]] |faces=3x4+8 [[triangle]]s
1+4 [[Square (geometry)|square]]s
1 [[octagon]] |edges=44 |vertices=20 |symmetry=''C''4v| |vertex_config=4(3.43)
2.4(33.8)
8(34.4) |dual=- |properties=[[convex set|convex]] |net=Johnson solid 23 net.png }} [[File:Yitcupola.jpg|250px|thumb|An unfolded gyroelongated square cupola]] [[File:Johnson solid 23 net.png|250px|thumb|An unfolded gyroelongated square cupola, faces colored by symmetry]] In [[geometry]], the '''gyroelongated square cupola''' is one of the [[Johnson solid]]s (''J''23). As the name suggests, it can be constructed by gyroelongating a [[square cupola]] (''J''4) by attaching an [[octagonal antiprism]] to its base. It can also be seen as a [[gyroelongated square bicupola]] (''J''45) with one square bicupola removed. {{Johnson solid}} == Dual polyhedron == The dual of the gyroelongated square cupola has 25 faces: 8 kites, 4 rhombi, and 8 pentagons. {| class=wikitable width=320 |- valign=top !Dual gyroelongated square cupola !Net of dual |- valign=top |[[File:Dual gyroelongated square cupola.png|160px]] |[[File:Dual gyroelongated square cupola net.png|160px]] |} ==External links== * {{mathworld2 | urlname2 = JohnsonSolid | title2 = Johnson solid| urlname = GyroelongatedSquareCupola | title = Gyroelongated square cupola }} {{Polyhedron-stub}} {{Johnson solids navigator}} [[Category:Johnson solids]]
